question: Question_06_(e)
statement:
\textbf{Full-Solution Problems}. In questions 5-11, justify your answers
and \textbf{show all your work}. If a box is provided, write your final
answer there. \textbf{Unless otherwise indicated, simplification of
numerical answers is required in these questions.}

6. Let $f(x) = 2x^{3/5} + 3x^{-2/5}$. Note that the domain of $f$ is the
set of all nonzero real numbers; for example, $f(-1) = -2 + 3 = 1$.

(e) Find all vertical asymptotes of the graph $y = f(x)$.
sols:
As given in the original statement, the function has domain of all
nonzero reals. The function itself is only not continuous at 0 so we
check there for an asymptote.

The value

\begin{align*}
\lim_{x \to 0^{+}}(2x^{3/5} + 3x^{-2/5}) = \infty
\end{align*} since this function when we plug in values of \emph{x}
slightly bigger than 0, the first term tends to 0 and the second term
tends to positive infinity.

Notice that the left hand limit is also positive infinity since the
second term can be written as
$\displaystyle 3x^{-2/5} = \frac{3}{\sqrt[5]{x^2}}$ which is always
positive.
hints:
Check points of the function where it is not continuous and verify that
one of the left or right hand limits are positive or negative infinity.
